Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I thought this course was really helpful for practicing speaking in Spanish, and Profe Valle gives a lot of feedback in correcting our grammar and sentence structure both in our writing and our speaking.
I improved my spanish quite a bit and learned about many current events issues.
My ability to speak and write in Spanish significantly improved from taking this course.  My speaking is much more fluid now, and my writing is even more grammatically precise.

I learned Spanish grammar, communication skills, and critical thinking in this L5 Spanish class. The focus was on refining our speaking and writing abilities, so weekly assignments included discussion forum posts and oral recordings, in addition to readings. I gained insight into how I could improve my pronunciation and vocabulary to make my communication in spanish more effective.

I really enjoyed the emphasis on speaking in this course. In particular, I wanted to maintain my speaking ability, but I found that the majority of L5 courses in Spanish prioritized the written component. While I did have the chance to write and to do so in a variety of different styles, most of class time was devoted to group or partner discussions. Each week, we also had to complete an oral in which we talked about that week's topic for five minutes or so in a relaxed manner. The orals in particular gave me the opportunity to go in-depth with a certain topic and gain confidence speaking for long-periods of time. Because of that, I feel that I could now engage in a debate, address a topic in-depth, or even give a speech in Spanish. Professor Valle also gives substantial feedback for each assignment. Thanks to her feedback, I have finally corrected grammar and pronunciation mistakes that I had been making for years.
My spoken Spanish improved greatly, and I got a good refresher in vocab and some grammar that we covered.

Strengths: workload is reasonable, expectations/syllabus are very clear, professor is helpful and wants everyone to succeed, discussion topics are generally interesting
Weaknesses: grammar practice not always thorough/at times repetitive
I feel like there could be more practice on the spoken component -- I still do feel a bit lacking in speaking ability (at least not native level yet)
I think the oral component of the course could be made further enriching and rigorous, but the writing parts were very helpful.

This course was excellent because it allowed me to engage in so many aspects of the Spanish language.  There were a mixture of reading, writing and speaking assignments that were all great practice, and the class discussions were always fascinating.  The novel was also very interesting and well-suited to the level of the class.  The only aspect of the class that could be improved is the focus on grammar.  It would have helped to have had a little more practice with some of the challenging grammatical concepts.  The workload was pretty heavy already, though.

The strengths of this course are the constant detailed feedback on all written and oral assignments. Also, readings are often assigned every class, which allows you to practice reading and critically analyzing Spanish literature both during and outside of class. The weakness of this course is that sometimes there were many assignments due on a single day, which made it very difficult to thoroughly read the assigned texts and complete all the work accompanying the reading. My advice would be to always start the homework the same day it is assigned, though I never did this.

The course is extremely well-structured. Professor Valle frequently uses Canvas to send out assignment reminders, submit oral recordings, and post responses on the discussion forum. I could often anticipate my workload for the week and then organize my assignments accordingly, so I never felt too overwhelmed. 

I also really enjoyed the course material. Often, I forgot I was in a Spanish language class, but felt that I was in a Spanish literature class. The seminar-style classes really emphasized discussion, and, with Professor Valle's encouragement, every person ended up contributing. The discussions and projects were also very entertaining. We had multiple debates, class dialogues, and role-playing. I frequently looked forward to completing the weekly readings, especially when we read Crnica de una muerte anunciada. 

The only thing I would change would be the partner format. Often, we would discuss a topic with a group and then take five minutes to discuss it in pairs. I think it might be helpful to have a consistent partner with a similar ability so that both people contribute equally.
There could have been more emphasis on grammar.

I thought it was a very great course to improve Spanish overall, including spoken Spanish which many other Yale Spanish L5 courses neglect. I wish there was even more focus on speaking and especially on casual, conversational Spanish!

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. I think it's a good fit for people coming out of high school having placed into L5 from the AP exam. The topics and instruction style are very similar to the way they are handled in the AP course, so the transition is not as difficult. In general, I think this course is a good practice for communicating in Spanish at a higher level.
The class and professor were super engaging, and I feel like my Spanish got a lot better. I would definitely recommend this course to another student.
Yes definitely!
Yes, to strong L5 speakers who want to improve their spanish as much as one could in a classroom section.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student because it significantly helped me to improve my Spanish.  The class discussions were excellent because we discussed real world issues while improving our Spanish as well.  There was a lot of work, but it was reasonable and very helpful.

Yes, I highly recommend this L5 Spanish course to anyone who has placed into L5 or has completed L4. I learned much more than I thought I would in one semester. The readings were sometimes quite challenging, but working through them before and during class truly solidified my love for Spanish literature. Furthermore, the weekly oral assignments made me constantly work towards better spoken pronunciation, grammar, and vocabulary.
Yes! It's a great bridge between L4 (Span 140) and the other L5's offered that are 200+ level.

Yes! I really enjoyed class and even the weekly readings. Professor Valle, in particular, is very encouraging and structures discussions so that all students participate. I especially wanted to work on my speaking ability, and I feel like I accomplished that with this course. Overall, a great experience.

Highly highly recommended, especially with Profa. Valle! It's not a whole lot of work (obviously there are assignments for every class meeting, but they're not extremely challenging). Your Spanish does improve a lot if you put in the effort, and it's a very fun, low key class overall.
